awd_titl_txt: II-New: A Research Platform for Heterogeneous, Massively Parallel Computing
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The world of computing has entered the multi-core age, as shown by the popularity of modern co-processors such as GPUs and FPGAs. Such hardware provided low-cost efficient platforms to satisfy the resource demands of many computational problems that cannot be easily handled by traditional CPU-based clusters. Therefore, the main objective of this project is to build a computer cluster with heterogeneous, massive parallel computing capabilities to accelerate existing research and enable ground-breaking new research that shares the same need for intensive computation at the University of South Florida (USF).

At the end of the project period, we have accomplished testing and deployment of a GPU-based HPC cluster named GAIVI (GPU-based Artificial Intelligence Video Intelligence) for academic research purposes. The high computing capability of GAIVI is powered by 24 GPU nodes with a total of 80 NVidia Titan X, 48 GTX 1080Ti GPU cards, and three Phi nodes with total of 21 Intel Xeon Phi cards. Such compute nodes are supported by two storage nodes with a total of 500TB usable disk space.

GAIVI was opened to faculty and students of USF for research purposes since June 2016. At this time, GAIVI has 134 registered users with affiliations in eight different academic departments at USF. In the last 12 months, GAIVI has accepted and processed customer tasks that consumed a total of 230,000 CPU hours. 

This project brings together eight investigators with research thrusts in several core disciplines of computer science and engineering: big data management, scientific computing, system security, hardware design, data mining, computer vision and pattern recognition. The new infrastructure further impacts over a dozen application domains via collaborative research projects among the investigators and their collaborators throughout the USF system. Research results from this project have been reported in 51 peer-reviewed articles, two PhD dissertations, and five MS theses.  

The broader impacts of this project are first seen from the application domains that benefit from the research projects. Applications such as cancer diagnosis, water management,  public health, video surveillance, pharmaceutical research carry high economical/societal value. The deployment and maintenance of the GAIVI cluster provided unique training opportunities for 3 PhD students in the management of an HPC facility. The computing resources of GAIVI enabled research for one postdoc, more than 10 PhD students, and 5 MS students in areas that are related to parallel computing, machine learning, and computer systems. We showed demos and interacted with more than 500 primary / middle school students in annual Engineering EXPO - an event to educate K-12 students on and motivate their interest in the STEM disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 09/03/2019
Modified by: Yicheng Tu
